body: Now you can make it static.

Of course, but static is a very good built-in test for bugs like this.
If it had been static you would have found this bug immediately.
And thank you for fix.

True, it would have found the bug. I'm sure I would have found another way to get it wrong. ;)

Since adding setLayoutDisabled, I have never actually found a use for it. May I ask why you need it?

:-)
In fact I don't see necessity for it in existing layout engine. I'm writing right now more complicated and rich engine. There it can be more useful, but I'm not sure. When I wrote my implementation of the method I found the bug.

Yes. Do you know Silverlight layout? I do something similar over Group class and compatible with original scene2d. I also support native Actors inside ExtLayout elements and ExtLayout elements inside Stage or native Group

I'm not familiar, but I like seeing how other layout libs work. So it is a two pass system. Android UI is also done this way, which I found added complexity versus a single pass. Android is pretty bad though, maybe Silverlight is better. :smile: Interesting what they call "layout slot". Bit strange that it clips, otherwise it's similar to TableLayout's logical table/cells, but forced on you at the lowest level versus building on top of a 2D scene graph. From the docs is seems it has no way to invalidate only a portion of the layout? Seems `Grid` is the main way to layout. Reminds me of [GridBagLayout](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zkJR9lmjqQo).

Any reason why you implement another layout versus using TableLayout?

There are 2 main reasons to implement something new:
1. default layouts very inconsistent. Any 2 actor types in connection parent-child behave absolutely different than any other 2 types
2. most of layouts doesn't allow programmer change their behavior by setting properties. Some behaviors are hard coded and require overriding methods (in good case) to change them.

My layout has properties for most behaviors, which are available for programmer. There are some common properties for any type of the element and they are treated by base class.Adding new type of the layout is very simple. You just need to override 2 functions: for calculating preferred size and to layout children. Base class does all dirty work.

1) Not sure what you mean? You'd prefer to force all actors to be laid out with the same layout manager?
2) I like to think [Table](https://github.com/EsotericSoftware/tablelayout) (a part of scene2d.ui) provides the customization needed for nearly any layout. Container, HorizontalGroup, VerticalGroup and Stack are also useful and configurable. What are you missing from these? I don't mean to be defensive, just curious how others perceive my pretty stuff. :wink: 

Widget/WidgetGroup sound like what you've described of your layout. To create a new type of layout, you subclass Widget/WidgetGroup, provide a pref size (min and max are optional) and implement `layout()` to size and position children. However, it is quite rare to need to create a new type of layout or to perform layout manually. Instead, Table can layout your actors for you.

Have you seen [Spine](http://esotericsoftware.com/)? It is a good example of a complex scene2d.ui app. There is also [Overlap2D](http://overlap2d.com/), [VBox2D](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6GAYqy4QJE0), and others.

1.No. I don't use layout manager. I just like consistent behavior, e.g. parent has some fixed width and any type of child inside should be shrank to this width, if I (as a programmer) didn't specify something else. In scene2d layout, image will be shrank, but verticalGroup with the same image inside - not. Because its minWidth is hardcoded as prefWidth. I don't remember exact situation for that problem, but I know it is and there are a lot of them.
2.I like different layouts. Each one for their special purpose. Grid is rich enough, but not universal. And grid in scene2d even less universal then mine. E.g. You cannot add more than one actor to the same cell. You cannot have one actor occupied one cell, second one occupied second cell and 3rd occupied both cells. And many other similar tricks. I don't understand why margins, alignment, etc. should be property of the cell. Why cannot I use the same properties for element inside vertical group or any other layout?

I haven't seen those layouts. I tried to find something, but failed. I found one (maybe one of them), but it was too complicated and not intuitive. So I created mine, based on well known Silverlight behavior. Anyway I'll look at them.
As I see, none of them has layout engine. They are implement flat game behavior or physics engine.

VerticalGroup has pretty specific usage, but Table can easily do what you want:

``` java
Table table = new Table();
table.add(anything).expandX().fillX().minWidth(0);
```

`expandX` makes the cell containing `anything` take up the entire width of the table, `fillX` makes `anything` to be sized to the cell in the x direction, and `minWidth` tells the cell to use 0 for the min width.

In scene2d.ui widgets provide a min, pref, and max size. You _could_ say this is hardcoded and not configurable, but it is not intended to be configurable. Instead it is just the widget providing what it thinks is it's own min, pref, and max size. Whatever is doing layout can use or ignore this information as needed, such as in the example 

Image shrinks in your example because it's mine size is 0,0. This is because an image can be scaled down below its pref size as needed. Other widgets return the pref size as the min size because for those widgets it doesn't make sense to size them smaller than the pref size. Eg, it doesn't make sense to size a Label smaller than the text it contains. If you want to you can, the label's min size is just telling its opinion.

2) Table doesn't have multiple actors per cell because I feel that would complicate the API. Instead, a Stack or nested Table can be used in the cell and then multiple actors put into that.

VerticalGroup does have many of the same properties as Table: alignment, padding, etc. Are you suggesting these be part of a base class for widgets? This would mean 1) the widget needs to know how to render respecting these properties (eg padding), which complicates widgets, or 2) every layout manager needs to take these properties into consideration, which complicates layout managers. Some layouts inevitably won't support some properties, which can be confusing (this plagues Swing and other toolkits). It is clean to keep widgets as just doing what they need, and to do layout customization completely in the layout manager.

Yeah, I was showing example apps built with scene2d.ui. :smile: I have a short list of layouts managers here:
https://github.com/EsotericSoftware/tablelayout#similar-libraries
DesignGridLayout is maybe the most interesting (besides TableLayout of course :wink:), as you mostly just add your widgets to it and it automatically does all the layout using canonical grids. Neat stuff, though not configurable.

I don't want to argue about which table, group, etc. is better. I want to tell you one fact.
We wrote our application layout during 2 months. Building one view took at least 2 days and lot of nerves. Then I built my layout (it took 2 weeks) and during 8 hours I converted all views to new layout. Then we continued to build application and now it takes 1-2 hours to build view of similar complexity. Everybody tells me that new layout engine is much more clear and consistent then the original. They say that it does exactly what you expect. I'm sorry, but this is the reality. At least in our group.
BTW, I created only layouts and not final widgets like image, button, etc. But ActorHost gives to any actor the same properties as any base element in my system has.

No arguing, I just explained my design choices. I'd prefer to discuss the actual merits of your system and the reasons why it's better, otherwise it simply sounds like you are more productive with a layout that you built yourself. Is your stuff OSS or online somewhere?
Still no, but I hope I will contribute it later. I just need to discuss it with my managers.

@urrri, I have similar problems with table layout... I do understand it, with all cell's expand/fill/align/min-pref-max sizes stuff, and I appreciate all it's flexibility... but it takes too much time to create create ui using Table layout.. And it's a nightmare when you have tons of ui. How is your progress with silverlight layout adaptation for libgdx? Any chance of contributions? I'm not familiar with it, but I'm very interested to see it!
@vlaaad, unfortunately I have no idea, when it will be clean. Our group was disbanded and I don't know who can give me rights to contribute the code. I'm trying to clear it.
